title: 115_hr4008
content:
The following sums are appropriated for fiscal year 2018 from Treasury funds and other revenues for various government departments, agencies, and organizations, including the Federal Emergency Management Agency's disaster relief fund. For fiscal year 2018, $18,670,000,000 is allocated to the Disaster Relief Fund for major disasters. $10,000,000 will be transferred to the Department of Homeland Security Office of Inspector General for audits and investigations. The specifics of public assistance grants over $1,000,000 must be published within 5 days. Mission assignments exceeding $1,000,000 must also be disclosed within 5 days. The Administrator will publish on the Agency's website details of disaster declarations, including the impacted State, assigned agency, assistance requested, disaster description, total cost estimate, and amount obligated. Updates on cost estimates and obligations must be provided monthly until completion. Specific spending estimates for Hurricane Harvey, Irma, and Maria disasters will be submitted to Congress and published monthly. The Administrator will publish monthly reports on the Agency's website detailing the cost of various spending categories for the current fiscal year, including public assistance, individual assistance, operations, mitigation, and administrative expenses. Up to $4.9 billion from the Disaster Relief Fund may be transferred to the Disaster Assistance Direct Loan Program Account to provide direct loans for local governments affected by Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, or Maria. The provision allows territories and possessions of the United States to receive loans exceeding $5,000,000 based on projected revenue losses and cash outlays for up to 180 days after a major disaster. It also permits multiple loans with specific repayment terms tailored to the type of revenue loss. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury, has the authority to cancel or modify loans issued to territories, possessions, and local governments. FEMA can transfer funds for administrative expenses related to the Disaster Assistance Direct Loan Program Account. The Congress authorizes the transfer of funds to the Disaster Assistance Direct Loan Program Account for administrative expenses and lending costs for territories affected by Hurricanes Irma or Maria. Additionally, funds are allocated for the Advance of Non-Federal Share program. The amount provided is designated as an emergency requirement. The Congress authorizes funds for the Disaster Assistance Direct Loan Program Account for territories affected by Hurricanes Irma or Maria, designated as an emergency requirement. The Department of Agriculture's Forest Service is allocated $184,500,000 for Wildland Fire Management for urgent fire suppression operations until September 30, 2021. The funds are designated as an emergency requirement and will be used to repay amounts transferred for wildfire suppression in fiscal year 2017. Additionally, there is a Flame Wildfire Suppression Reserve Fund for transferring funds. The FLAME Wildfire Suppression Reserve Fund is allocated an additional $342,000,000 for large wildland fire suppression operations of the Department of Agriculture. The funds are to remain available through September 30, 2021, and are designated as an emergency requirement. The funds can be transferred to other appropriations accounts to fully repay amounts transferred for wildfire suppression in fiscal year 2017. Department-Wide Programs include wildland fire management with an additional $50,000,000 allocated for urgent fire suppression activities. The funds can be transferred to other accounts to repay previous transfers for wildfire suppression. The amount is designated as an emergency requirement. Sec. 301 - Additional appropriations made by this Act.
Sec. 302 - Appropriations not available beyond current fiscal year.
Sec. 303 - Terms and conditions apply to funds in this Act and Public Law 115-56.
Sec. 304 - Emergency designated amounts available upon President's designation.
Sec. 305 - Federal agencies to submit reports by December 31, 2017. Federal agencies must submit internal control plans for funds provided by this Act and division B of Public Law 115-56 to OMB, the Government Accountability Office, agency Inspector Generals, and the Committees on Appropriations. The Government Accountability Office will review the design of these plans by March 31, 2018. All programs receiving funds are considered susceptible to improper payments. Grants must be expended within 24 months unless a waiver is granted by the Director of OMB with justification submitted to the Committees. Director waives the requirement for a grant program and provides a written justification to Congress. Grants must be spent within 24 months, with funds not used to be returned. Amendments are made to include Indian tribes in certain grants. Repurposed funds are designated as emergency requirements. Sec. 307 amends the Department of the Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2017. Sec. 308 allocates $16 billion to address outstanding indebtedness under certain flood insurance acts. The Act allocates $16 billion to cancel outstanding indebtedness under certain flood insurance acts. The Administrator and National Flood Insurance Fund are relieved of liability to the Treasury for the canceled amount. The canceled debt may be treated as public debt. The section is designated as an emergency requirement by Congress. Sec. 309. $1,270,000,000 from the contingency reserve for Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program in Public Law 114-113 is available for Puerto Rico for disaster nutrition assistance until September 30, 2019. This amount is designated by Congress as an emergency requirement. During fiscal year 2018, the dollar limitation on advance billing of a customer of a working-capital fund does not apply to the Federal Emergency Management Agency. This Act is known as the "Additional Supplemental Appropriations for Disaster Relief Requirements Act of 2017."
